awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Drug Delivery Micro-device for Age-related Macular Degeneration
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this EAGER grant is to investigate the feasibility and assess the integrity of the implantable device design through computational simulations and optimizing the design for a specific flow rate and delivery time. This objective will be accomplished by implementing the following tasks: (i) Develop design concepts and conduct computational simulations through nano-channel arrays of varying length, height and width, and simulate the drug release kinetics for several candidate drug molecules; and (ii) Optimize the design for specific flow rate and delivery time. Based on the optimized design, a prototype model will be explored. This approach of using computations and design optimization for drug device design and integrity has never been examined for AMD devices due to challenges in size and extended delivery time.
Intellectual merit
This project is a high-risk and high payoff and will provide a fundamental understanding of the physical and mechanical interactions through nano-channels of the drug delivery design and will provide valuable scientific insights into integration characteristics and implantable drug delivery devices. Investigating the design integrity and integration of implantable devices for AMD such as the one proposed in this EAGER project will help reduce the costs and risks associated with frequent injections and promote delivering the drug in a controlled manner and in the required amounts for treating AMD disease.
Broader impacts
This project will design and develop a novel implantable drug delivery device incorporating nano-channels with controlled drug kinetics and delivery time for treating AMD, and thereby benefit society at large. This project will provide undergraduate and graduate students with multidisciplinary knowledge and training related to drug delivery devices, computational studies and optimization. The research results will be integrated into courses the PI?s teach in the ME and ECE curricula. The VCU School of engineering?s summer enrichment programs will be expanded to include this project related work in outreach activities with high school students.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, a conceptual design, computational simulations, fabrication and limited testing was carried out for an implantable drug delivery device for treating ocular diseases such as age-related macular degeneration. Several research issues related to design, fabrication, experiments, and simulations were investigated. The implantable drug delivery concept using micro/nano-channels and the computational simulations demonstrated the potential for drug delivery applications.

 

An implantable drug delivery device with several micro/nano channels concepts were developed for a variety of drug delivery rates and investigated drug diffusion characteristics through fabrication and testing as well as simulations. We have successfully conducted computational fluid dynamics simulations through various channel configurations in order to obtain the drug diffusion characteristics of the designed device concept. The results from the simulation studies revealed information related to drug transport under varying design parameters. The design simulations were conducted with a desired rate was achieved. Based on results from several simulations, an optimization study was conducted to achieve the required dosage for about 2 years. The results obtained from the optimization study shows that the developed device concept can be extended for different drugs to treat ocular diseases including age-related macular degeneration (AMD). In addition, we also conducted the implantable device with four different micro-channel configurations for ocular drug delivery. Drug diffusion characteristics were examined using both experimental measurement and computer simulations. According to comparison between simulation and experimental results, three designed channel configurations were found to be capable of sustaining drug release and meet the required design requirements of the developed device. It was observed that altering the surface chemistry of the device has no significant effect on the delivery rate of the model drugs. The Straight and Leaf designs most closely matched the required dosages of Lucentis and Intravitrea Avastin. However, all three designs provided a constant delivery of the model drugs after 24 hours. An investigation to study the effect of the microchannel configuration of the microdevice, the size of drug-loaded nanoparticles, and the pressure gradient of fluid flow is carried out using a hybrid computational approach that combines the lattice Boltzmann model for fluids with the Brownian dynamics model for nanoparticles transport. The results obtained showed that increasing the pressure gradient of fluid flow in a specific type of microchannel configuration (tournament configuration) effectively decreased the maximum number of nanoparticles within a certain outlet region as well as transportation time of the drug loaded nanoparticles.

 

Broader impacts include graduate/undergraduate student training, undergraduate projects and research integration into the curriculum, and expanding the project to include other investigators. The research results were presented at several conferences as well as meetings. Attracted several underrepresented students to this project to pursue bioengineering research and provided opportunities for advanced studies.


Last Modified: 01/25/2017
Modified by: Ramana M Pidaparti
